issue.title: Use cryptography version >=35
issue.body:
The `cryptography` package version 35.0.0 changed the behavior of `x509.load_pem_x509_certificate()` which now raises the following when it gets combined key-and-cert PEM data.

```
ValueError: Valid PEM but no BEGIN CERTIFICATE/END CERTIFICATE delimiters. Are you sure this is a certificate?
```

Either find a way to pass only the `BEGIN/END CERTIFICATE` portion, or wait and see if `cryptography` changes the behavior of this function back.

For the time being, `<35` has been added to the project and tox dependencies.

body:
This is a docs issue -- we originally flagged this issue in the changelog but then incorrectly removed it.

We need to add back the note that PEM parsers only accept a parse of the desired type.

I'm happy to do it correctly.  Is there an idiomatic way to separate the key and cert?  I could write my own parser pretty easily, but I'd rather reuse an implementation that's already being maintained if I can.

The pem package from PyPI will probably do exactly what you need.
Unfortunately we don't have a direct API for doing this ourselves (maybe
it's fine for one...)

On Fri, Oct 1, 2021 at 7:27 AM Bill Allen ***@***.***> wrote:

> I'm happy to do it correctly. Is there an idiomatic way to separate the
> key and cert? I could write my own parser pretty easily, but I'd rather
> reuse an implementation that's already being maintained if I can.
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/6351#issuecomment-932147049>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAAAGBDGCEYVAB3VNFGVUJTUEWLJ3ANCNFSM5FENZXBQ>
> .
> Triage notifications on the go with GitHub Mobile for iOS
> <https://apps.apple.com/app/apple-store/id1477376905?ct=notification-email&mt=8&pt=524675>
> or Android

>
>


-- 
All that is necessary for evil to succeed is for good people to do nothing.

It would be useful to provide an high level API that deals with files that contain multiple certificates, private key, PEM preambles and epilogs. It's common to have private key, EE cert, and intermediate certs with additional information in a single file.

```
x509.parse_pem(data: bytes) -> List[Tuple[PemTypeEnum, bytes]]
```

The first item of the tuple encodes the PEM type (certificate, private key, CRL, text) and the second member is the PEM block (with header and footer) or the raw ``text`` if it's extra text.

repository.name: mitmproxy
repository.description: An interactive TLS-capable intercepting HTTP proxy for penetration testers and software developers.

issue.title: `parse_many` silently discards invalid sections
issue.body:
First off, thanks for the super helpful project! :cake:

I was looking at exposing `pem::parse_many` to Python users via the `cryptography` package (https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/6351#issuecomment-932148321). In that process I discovered that `parse_many` silently discards all invalid sections, which I found quite surprising. That makes it hard to provide good error messages as I cannot differentiate between malformed and missing sections.

Long story short, would you entertain the idea of either changing `parse_many` to return a `Result<Vec<Pem>>` or adding an alternative method name (`parse_all`, `parse_many_strict`?) that returns an error on the first parsing failure? I'd be happy to send a PR with whatever you prefer. ðŸ˜ƒ 

For reference, here's the current `parse_many` implementation: 

https://github.com/jcreekmore/pem-rs/blob/b2cfec184815fecace9b5b1844eb6b15bda69793/src/lib.rs#L320-L326

body:
I feel this is quite a common use case. @tiran's high level API sounds good, from a convenience perspective it would be super nice if `load_pem_x509_certificate` would just parse the entire PEM file and return a certificate object iff there is exactly one `CERTIFICATE` section. That saves everyone from reimplementing the same for loop iterating through `parse_pem` results.


FWIW I took a brief look at implementing this using the `pem` crate in Rust, but that seems to need some upstream changes first (see linked issue above this message).

Looks like there's very quick movement on changes to the `pem` crate to support this. I'd be in favor of landing this API sooner rather than later since it seems like this is a relatively common behavior. This might make a quick 36.0.0 ðŸ˜‚

Yes, @jcreekmore has been amazingly responsive, there are no upstream blockers anymore on the Rust side. ðŸ°

I can get this rolling tomorrow if noone wants to beat me to it.

1. Are there any strong objections to my proposal in https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/6351#issuecomment-932284647?
2. Do we have opinions on `parse_pem` returning a `(type: PemTypeEnum, data: bytes)` tuple vs returning a `(type: str, data: bytes)` tuple? After working with the pem crate I feel that this could be low-level enough for the former to be more of a nuisance than anything else, but it's not a hill I'm planning to die on. :)

1. I think we should restore the previous behavior -- I think your description of it makes sense.
2. Once we have (1), I'm not sure we need `parse_pem`. But if we do want to add it, I think we should just model it on Go's: https://pkg.go.dev/encoding/pem#Block

issue.title: Accept combined PEM files with multiple sections

repository.name: cryptography
repository.description: cryptography is a package designed to expose cryptographic primitives and recipes to Python developers.

issue.body:
This PR adds a `find_in_pem` on the Rust side, which filters out unrelated PEM sections and returns the matching one. This makes it possible to read combined key-and-cert PEM files again (#6351).

If multiple sections are found that match our criteria, we error. I'm not sure if this matches the pre-35.0 behavior, but I feel it's not a particulary good idea to let that go through unnoticed. :)
